title: Ancient & Classical Philosophy
description: Focus on Pre-Socratic thinkers, Socratic dialogues, and Plato's foundational ideas. Based on Open Yale lectures.

learningObjectives.description: Understand core concepts from Pre-Socratic philosophy, Socrates' method, and Plato’s Theory of Forms
assessmentCriteria: Identify major Pre-Socratic contributions
Explain the Socratic method’s function in dialogues

resources.title: Open Yale Course: Introduction to Ancient Greek Philosophy
resources.content: Lecture series covering early Greek philosophers, Socrates, Plato

assignments.title: Short Essay: Socratic Dialogue Reflection
assignments.description: Write 500 words on how Socratic questioning can apply to modern ethical issues.

questions.title: Modern Socratic Method
questions.description: Discuss a current ethical debate and how Socratic questioning might clarify it.

assignments.title: Group Presentation: Pre-Socratic vs. Platonic Thought
assignments.description: In groups of 3, compare two Pre-Socratic philosophers with Plato’s ideas. Present for ~10 minutes.

questions.title: Comparative Analysis
questions.description: Highlight differences in metaphysics, method, and impact on modern philosophy.

quizzes.title: Classical Philosophy Basics
quizzes.description: Quick check on Pre-Socratic figures, Socratic method, Plato's main concepts.

questions.title: Which philosopher introduced the Theory of Forms?
Heraclitus believed in a static, unchanging reality.

quizzes.title: Socratic & Platonic Thought Quiz
quizzes.description: Additional practice assessing knowledge on Socratic dialogues and Plato’s influences.

questions.title: Socrates often claimed he knew nothing, a stance known as:
Define the Socratic Method in 1-2 sentences.

title: Modern & Contemporary Philosophy
description: Descartes, Kant, Nietzsche, and modern philosophical debates. References Yale moral & modern philosophy lectures.

learningObjectives.description: Analyze key modern thinkers and their influence on ethics, epistemology, and existential questions
assessmentCriteria: Evaluate Descartes’ rationalism
Contrast Kant’s deontological ethics with Nietzsche’s moral skepticism

resources.title: Open Yale Course: Moral Foundations & Modern Thinkers
resources.content: Lectures covering Kant, Mill, Nietzsche, modern moral philosophy

assignments.title: Essay: Kant vs. Nietzsche
assignments.description: Write ~1000 words contrasting Kant’s categorical imperative with Nietzsche’s critique of morality.

questions.title: Moral Frameworks
questions.description: Provide concrete examples. Cite at least one Yale lecture.

assignments.title: Short Response: Descartes' Cogito
assignments.description: Write a ~300-word response on the implications of “I think, therefore I am.”

questions.title: Rationalism in Modern Thought
questions.description: Reflect on how Descartes' 'Cogito' shapes modern epistemology.

quizzes.title: Modern Philosophy Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice and short-answer questions on Descartes, Kant, Nietzsche, and existential thinkers.

questions.title: Which phrase is attributed to Descartes?
options: "The unexamined life is not worth living"

questions.title: Explain how Nietzsche challenges traditional morality in 2-3 sentences.

quizzes.title: Kantian & Existential Challenges
quizzes.description: Focused quiz on Kant’s moral principles vs. existential critiques.

questions.title: Kant’s categorical imperative is a consequentialist approach to ethics.
Which philosopher is strongly associated with existentialism?

title: Ethics & Political Philosophy
description: Explores utilitarianism, deontology, social contract, and political ideologies. References additional Yale political philosophy lectures.

learningObjectives.description: Compare and evaluate major ethical frameworks and their political implications
assessmentCriteria: Discuss the social contract (Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau)
Analyze utilitarian vs. deontological stances in political contexts

resources.title: Yale Political Philosophy Lectures
resources.content: Lectures on liberalism, conservatism, socialism, and social contract theories

assignments.title: Policy Analysis Paper
assignments.description: Pick a contemporary policy issue (e.g., healthcare) and evaluate it using both utilitarian and deontological frameworks.

questions.title: Ethical Contrast
questions.description: Apply each framework thoroughly with references to real-world outcomes.

assignments.title: Debate Reflection: Social Contract Theories
assignments.description: Attend or watch a debate on social contract theory. Write a 400-word reflection analyzing key points.

questions.title: Debate Summary
questions.description: Identify at least two arguments for and two against the social contract model.

quizzes.title: Ethical Frameworks Quiz
quizzes.description: Check knowledge of deontology, utilitarianism, and social contract basics.

questions.title: Which philosopher is known for the principle of 'the greatest good for the greatest number'?
Hobbes believed humans are naturally inclined to peaceful cooperation in the state of nature.

quizzes.title: Political Philosophy Quick Check
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice and short-answer about liberalism, conservatism, socialism, and their ethical roots.

questions.title: Which philosopher is associated with 'Leviathan' and a strong central authority?
Define 'social contract' in 2-3 sentences.

title: Logic, Existentialism & Contemporary Debates
description: Introduction to formal logic, existentialist themes (Sartre, Camus), and current philosophical debates.

learningObjectives.description: Apply basic logic to evaluate arguments and understand existential perspectives in modern issues
assessmentCriteria: Identify valid vs. invalid argument forms
Summarize existentialist responses to meaning, freedom, authenticity

resources.title: Yale Logic Lectures & Existential Debates
resources.content: Intro to logic plus existentialists like Kierkegaard, Sartre, Camus

assignments.title: Formal Logic Worksheet
assignments.description: Identify valid/invalid arguments, label informal fallacies, and propose corrected forms.

questions.title: Fallacy Identification
questions.description: Spot the ad hominem, straw man, or slippery slope in sample statements.

questions.title: Argument Correction
questions.description: Rewrite an invalid argument to make it valid (formally).

assignments.title: Existential Reflection Paper
assignments.description: 2000-word paper exploring how existential ideas apply to personal freedom or modern crises (climate, AI, etc.).

questions.title: Existential Inquiry
questions.description: Incorporate at least one existential thinker (Sartre, Camus) and discuss personal authenticity or ethical choices.

quizzes.title: Logic Fundamentals Quiz
quizzes.description: Identify valid argument forms, recognize common fallacies.

questions.title: Which of the following is a valid deductive form?
A straw man fallacy misrepresents an opponent’s position to make it easier to attack.

quizzes.title: Existentialism & Modern Issues Quiz
quizzes.description: Short check on existential themes from Kierkegaard, Sartre, Camus, and current debates.

questions.title: Which existentialist stated, 'Existence precedes essence'?
Briefly define 'absurdism' in Camus's philosophy.

title: Foundations of Personality
description: Introduces Big Five model, trait theory, and Jordan Peterson’s perspectives from his open lectures.

learningObjectives.description: Identify and describe key personality models and examine role of genetics vs. environment
assessmentCriteria: Big Five trait definitions
Heritability evidence

resources.title: Jordan Peterson: Personality and Its Transformations
resources.content: Lecture series covering personality psychology, trait theory, transformations

assignments.title: Personality Inventory & Reflection
assignments.description: Complete a Big Five inventory and write a reflective piece on the results.

questions.title: Big Five Results
questions.description: Summarize your scores and any surprises.

questions.title: Nature vs. Nurture
questions.description: Reflect on how upbringing or genetics influenced at least two traits.

assignments.title: Research Article Review
assignments.description: Locate a peer-reviewed study on personality stability. Summarize methods, results, and your critique.

questions.title: Study Critique
questions.description: Highlight strengths, weaknesses, and relation to the Big Five model.

quizzes.title: Big Five Basics
quizzes.description: Short quiz on trait definitions and Peterson’s foundational concepts.

questions.title: Which trait is NOT part of the Big Five?
Peterson's lectures argue that biological factors are irrelevant to personality.

quizzes.title: Trait Theory & Heritability
quizzes.description: Checks deeper knowledge of how genetics and environment interact in personality formation.

questions.title: Define 'heritability' in the context of personality psychology.
questions.description: 1-2 sentences.

questions.title: Which approach examines how genes and environment jointly influence trait development?

title: Personality Development & Transformation
description: Explores how personality evolves across the lifespan, referencing deeper Jordan Peterson lectures.

learningObjectives.description: Examine life events and therapeutic methods that alter personality over time
assessmentCriteria: Evaluate effects of major life transitions
Identify at least two therapy forms influencing trait change

resources.title: Jordan Peterson: Advanced Transformations Lectures
resources.content: Open lectures discussing personality evolution, therapy, major transformations

assignments.title: Case Study: Personality Shift
assignments.description: Interview someone who experienced a significant life change and analyze how it affected their personality.

questions.title: Interview Summary
questions.description: Key life events and trait changes observed.

questions.title: Link to Theory
questions.description: Relate changes to recognized psychological theories or Peterson’s content.

assignments.title: Therapy Comparative Analysis
assignments.description: Brief paper contrasting CBT vs. psychodynamic therapy in terms of altering personality traits.

questions.title: Therapeutic Influences
questions.description: Discuss how each approach might shift conscientiousness or neuroticism.

quizzes.title: Personality Transformation Quiz
quizzes.description: Knowledge check on how therapy, life transitions, environment can shift traits.

questions.title: Which therapy focuses on altering core beliefs and thought patterns?
Define 'critical life event' in personality psychology (1-2 sentences).

quizzes.title: Life Transitions & Therapy Methods
quizzes.description: Short quiz on major life transitions and different therapeutic modalities.

questions.title: Humanistic therapy generally ignores the individual's subjective experience.
Which major milestone is typically associated with a reevaluation of personality?

title: Clinical & Therapeutic Approaches
description: Focus on how clinical settings, e.g. CBT, psychodynamic, and group therapy, shape or modify personality traits.

learningObjectives.description: Differentiate key therapeutic approaches and explain their impact on personality development
assessmentCriteria: Describe core principles of CBT, psychodynamic, and humanistic approaches
Identify typical personality-related outcomes

resources.title: Jordan Peterson Clinical Psychology Lectures
resources.content: Talks about therapy, personal development, transformation

assignments.title: Therapy Session Analysis
assignments.description: Watch a recorded or simulated therapy session (publicly available). Write a short analysis linking to personality outcomes.

questions.title: Session Summary
questions.description: Key therapeutic techniques observed.

questions.title: Impact on Traits
questions.description: Discuss how therapy might alter neuroticism, openness, etc.

assignments.title: Group Presentation: Therapy Modalities
assignments.description: Groups of 3 pick a modality (CBT, psychoanalysis, etc.) and present a 10-min summary of how it shifts personality patterns.

questions.title: Therapy Modality Presentation
questions.description: Explain core theory, typical client outcomes, and strengths/weaknesses.

quizzes.title: Therapy Approach Basics
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice and short-answer on CBT, psychodynamic, humanistic, group therapy concepts.

questions.title: Which approach often explores early childhood to uncover unconscious motives?
Name one advantage and one limitation of group therapy for personality change.

quizzes.title: Clinical Psychology Terms Quiz
quizzes.description: Quick check on common clinical terms like transference, countertransference, unconditional positive regard, etc.

questions.title: Which term describes a client's projection of feelings about important figures onto their therapist?
Unconditional positive regard is central to psychodynamic therapy.

title: Cultural & Biological Perspectives on Personality
description: Investigates how culture, society, and neurobiology shape personality development, referencing advanced Peterson materials.

learningObjectives.description: Analyze the interplay between cultural context, biological factors, and personality formation
assessmentCriteria: Examine cross-cultural studies on personality traits
Discuss neurobiological correlates of trait differences

resources.title: Jordan Peterson: Biology & Culture (selected talks)
resources.content: Lectures on how society and biology shape personality over time

assignments.title: Cross-Cultural Personality Study
assignments.description: Find a research article comparing personality across different cultures. Critique methodology, results, and cultural context.

questions.title: Study Critique
questions.description: Evaluate sample, measurement tools, and the authors’ interpretation. Relate to course materials.

assignments.title: Neurobiological Basis of Personality
assignments.description: Write a 1200-word paper discussing how brain regions (e.g., amygdala, prefrontal cortex) correlate with specific traits.

questions.title: Biological Correlates of Personality
questions.description: Cite at least two neuroscience studies or references from Jordan Peterson's lectures.

quizzes.title: Culture & Personality Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice and short-answer on cross-cultural differences in trait expression.

questions.title: Which statement best captures cross-cultural personality research?
options: All cultures share identical trait distributions
Culture has no impact on trait manifestations
Culture can influence mean trait levels and behavioral expressions
Only genetics matter for personality development

questions.title: Define 'cultural dimension' in the context of personality psychology.
questions.description: 1-2 sentences.

quizzes.title: Biological Factors & Personality
quizzes.description: Assesses knowledge of neurobiological correlates with personality traits.

questions.title: Which brain structure is often linked to fear responses and trait neuroticism?
Prefrontal cortex activity has no correlation with conscientiousness.

title: Front-End Foundations
description: Introduction to HTML, CSS, and basic JavaScript, referencing Harvard CS50 & MIT tutorials on front-end.

learningObjectives.description: Build basic, responsive web pages with semantic HTML/CSS and simple DOM manipulation
assessmentCriteria: Use semantic HTML tags
Implement a responsive layout with Flexbox/Grid

assignments.title: Personal Profile Page
assignments.description: Create a personal profile site with at least two pages, a responsive layout, and minimal JS interactivity.

questions.title: HTML/CSS Structure
questions.description: Use semantic tags, style with Flexbox or Grid, ensure mobile responsiveness.

questions.title: JS Interactivity
questions.description: Add at least one interactive feature (like a form validation or dynamic content).

assignments.title: CSS Layout Challenge
assignments.description: Recreate a given mockup focusing on advanced layout (Grid, Flexbox). Must be fully responsive.

questions.title: Layout Replication
questions.description: Match the design specs closely, handle breakpoints for mobile/tablet/desktop.

quizzes.title: Front-End Basics Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice & short-answer on HTML, CSS, basic JS syntax.

questions.title: Which tag is used for the largest heading in HTML?
Explain the difference between margin and padding in 1-2 sentences.

quizzes.title: CSS & DOM Quiz
quizzes.description: Focus on advanced CSS (Grid, Flexbox) and basic DOM manipulation events.

questions.title: Which CSS property is used to create a grid layout?
Name one method to attach an event listener in JavaScript.

title: Intermediate Front-End & Tooling
description: Deep dive into DOM manipulation, asynchronous JS (fetch), and dev tools. Also covers basic bundlers/build tools.

learningObjectives.description: Create dynamic UIs with JavaScript event handling, fetch API, and basic build processes
assessmentCriteria: Implement asynchronous data fetching
Use browser dev tools for debugging

resources.title: CS50 Lectures: DOM, Async JS, and Build Tools
resources.content: Guidance on advanced front-end patterns, including fetch API, webpack, etc.

assignments.title: SPA Fetch Project
assignments.description: Build a small Single Page App using only vanilla JS. Fetch data from a public API and display dynamically.

questions.title: Fetch & Render
questions.description: Retrieve JSON from an open API, display in the DOM with minimal reloading.

questions.title: Event Handling & Error Handling
questions.description: Show loading states, handle errors gracefully, incorporate at least 2 user-triggered events.

assignments.title: Debugging Exercise
assignments.description: Given a buggy front-end, use browser dev tools to identify errors. Submit a short report on solutions.

questions.title: Bug Summary
questions.description: Detail the main issues and how you located them.

questions.title: Fix Implementation
questions.description: Show the corrected code or patches for each bug found.

quizzes.title: Async & DOM Quiz
quizzes.description: Covers fetch API usage, promises, event handling, plus some dev tooling basics.

questions.title: Which method returns a promise that resolves to a Response object of the request?
Name one advantage of using a build tool (like webpack or parcel).

quizzes.title: Tooling & Dev Tools Quiz
quizzes.description: Focuses on debugging, bundlers, and performance checks.

questions.title: Source maps help map minified code back to original source files.
Which Chrome DevTools feature allows you to inspect real-time performance metrics?

title: Server-Side Fundamentals: Node.js, Express, and Databases
description: Intro to Node.js server-side, Express routing, plus either SQL or NoSQL databases. Uses Harvard CS50 & MIT resources.

learningObjectives.description: Build and deploy simple server-side apps using Node.js, Express, and a database
assessmentCriteria: Implement RESTful routes
Handle errors, parse JSON data

resources.title: Harvard CS50: Introduction to Back-End, Databases
resources.content: Lectures covering server basics, Express, SQL, and NoSQL

assignments.title: Node.js/Express CRUD App
assignments.description: Create a basic resource manager with GET, POST, PUT, DELETE endpoints. Choose SQLite or MongoDB for storage.

questions.title: Server Setup & Routing
questions.description: Implement Express routes for listing, creating, updating, deleting resources.

questions.title: Database Integration
questions.description: Explain how you connect to and interact with your chosen database.

assignments.title: Error Handling & Logging
assignments.description: Enhance your CRUD app with robust error handling (404, 500) and basic request logging. Submit short doc on approach.

questions.title: Add Custom Error Responses
questions.description: Handle invalid routes or data with friendly error messages.

questions.title: Logging Strategy
questions.description: Outline how you log requests and errors (e.g. Morgan, Winston).

quizzes.title: Server & REST Quiz
quizzes.description: Questions on Node.js basics, Express routing, HTTP methods.

questions.title: Which HTTP method is typically used to update an existing resource?
Express cannot parse JSON data without a middleware like body-parser or express.json.

quizzes.title: Database Fundamentals Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice & short-answer on relational vs. non-relational DBs, basic SQL commands.

questions.title: Which is a NoSQL database?
Give one example of a basic SQL statement for creating a table.

title: Advanced Topics & Deployment
description: Focus on advanced back-end patterns, authentication, and deployment. Summarize the full-stack capstone project.

learningObjectives.description: Implement authentication, advanced back-end features, and deploy a full-stack application
assessmentCriteria: Set up basic user auth
Deploy app to a cloud platform

resources.title: CS50 Database & Cloud Deployment
resources.content: Introduces SQL advanced concepts, NoSQL, and deployment on Heroku/AWS

assignments.title: User Authentication Integration
assignments.description: Add signup/login functionality to your Node/Express app. Implement session or token-based auth.

questions.title: Auth Routes & Middleware
questions.description: Protect certain routes, require login to access them. Provide a basic login form (if front-end integrated).

questions.title: Security Considerations
questions.description: Explain how you handle password hashing, sessions, or JWT tokens.

assignments.title: Capstone: Full-Stack Project
assignments.description: In groups of up to 4, create a fully functional app with front-end, back-end, DB, and deploy to a cloud platform (Heroku, Netlify, etc.).

questions.title: Project Demo & Architecture
questions.description: Include a short doc or slides explaining your tech stack, DB schema, front-end, and deployment steps.

quizzes.title: Authentication & Security Quiz
quizzes.description: Tests knowledge of hashing, sessions, tokens, and security best practices.

questions.title: Which hashing algorithm is commonly recommended for passwords?
Storing plain-text passwords in your database is acceptable for small projects.

quizzes.title: Deployment & Scaling Quiz
quizzes.description: Short quiz on cloud hosting, environment variables, and performance considerations.

questions.title: What is an environment variable, and why is it important in deployment?
Which service is NOT typically used for hosting Node.js apps?
options: GoDaddy (shared cPanel hosting without Node support)

title: Neuroanatomy & Brain Structures
description: Focus on major brain regions, referencing Andrew Huberman’s foundational talks and MIT OpenCourseWare resources.

learningObjectives.description: Identify the main areas of the brain and describe their primary functions
assessmentCriteria: Label cortical lobes, subcortical areas
Explain roles of hippocampus and amygdala

resources.title: Andrew Huberman Lab: Brain Anatomy Basics
resources.content: Intro discussions on major brain structures

assignments.title: Brain Diagram Labeling
assignments.description: Download a blank brain diagram, label lobes/subcortical structures, provide brief functional notes.

questions.title: Brain Regions
questions.description: Ensure correct labeling of frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal lobes, plus hippocampus, amygdala.

assignments.title: Neuroanatomy Short Essay
assignments.description: Write ~500 words on how understanding brain regions can inform medical or psychological interventions.

questions.title: Practical Neuroanatomy
questions.description: Discuss real-world relevance for therapy or neurosurgery examples.

quizzes.title: Neuroanatomy Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice/short-answer on major brain structures and their basic functions.

questions.title: Which lobe is primarily responsible for visual processing?
Explain the primary role of the hippocampus in 1-2 sentences.

quizzes.title: Brain Structures & Functions Check
quizzes.description: Additional check on subcortical structures, including amygdala, basal ganglia, cerebellum.

questions.title: Which structure is most involved in emotional processing, especially fear?
The cerebellum primarily coordinates cognitive function rather than motor control.

title: Neuronal Communication & Plasticity
description: Explores how neurons communicate (action potentials, synapses) and introduces concepts of neuroplasticity.

learningObjectives.description: Describe action potentials, synaptic transmission, and principles of brain plasticity
assessmentCriteria: Outline steps of an action potential
Discuss how experience can reshape neuronal connections

resources.title: Andrew Huberman: Synapses & Plasticity Talks
resources.content: Discussions on neuronal firing, synaptic changes, and learning

assignments.title: Neuron Firing Simulation Report
assignments.description: Use an online action potential simulator (HHsim). Adjust ion concentrations, record changes, submit short report.

questions.title: Simulation Setup
questions.description: Summarize how you configured sodium/potassium channels.

questions.title: Analysis of Results
questions.description: Explain how altering ion channels affected the AP amplitude or threshold. Cite Huberman's lecture if relevant.

assignments.title: Plasticity Case Study
assignments.description: Find a published case study of brain plasticity (e.g., stroke recovery) and write a 600-word summary.

questions.title: Case Study Summary & Discussion
questions.description: Highlight the neural changes observed, referencing at least one concept from lecture (LTP, neurogenesis, etc.).

quizzes.title: Synaptic Transmission & Plasticity
quizzes.description: Short quiz on basic neurotransmission steps, excitatory vs. inhibitory synapses, neuroplasticity.

questions.title: Which ion primarily triggers neurotransmitter release?
Neuroplasticity only occurs during childhood and cannot happen in adulthood.

quizzes.title: Advanced Neuroplasticity Check
quizzes.description: Additional quiz focusing on LTP, LTD, and real-world implications of plasticity.

questions.title: Define 'long-term potentiation' in 1-2 sentences.
Which factor is NOT typically associated with enhancing neuroplasticity?

title: Sensory & Motor Systems
description: Study how the brain processes sensory inputs (vision, hearing, etc.) and coordinates motor outputs. References MIT OCW and Huberman on vision & movement.

learningObjectives.description: Describe pathways for key senses and the neural control of movement
assessmentCriteria: Illustrate visual pathway from retina to visual cortex
Explain motor cortex and basal ganglia roles

resources.title: MIT OpenCourseWare: Sensory & Motor Systems
resources.content: In-depth coverage of how the brain interprets sensory data and executes motor control

resources.title: Huberman Lab: Vision & Movement Episodes
resources.content: Discussions of the neuroscience behind sight and motor coordination

assignments.title: Visual Pathway Diagram
assignments.description: Create a flowchart showing how visual signals travel from retina to V1, noting key relay stations.

questions.title: Retina-to-Visual Cortex
questions.description: Include optic nerve, chiasm, LGN, and primary visual cortex labeling.

assignments.title: Motor Control Mini-Report
assignments.description: Discuss a disorder affecting motor control (e.g. Parkinson’s) and relate it to basal ganglia function.

questions.title: Motor Disorder & Basal Ganglia
questions.description: Explain how impairment leads to motor symptoms, referencing at least one lecture.

quizzes.title: Sensory Systems Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice on visual, auditory, and somatosensory pathways.

questions.title: Which thalamic nucleus relays visual information to the cortex?
Auditory information does not pass through any thalamic nucleus before reaching the cortex.

quizzes.title: Motor Control Check
quizzes.description: Short quiz on motor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum involvement in movement.

questions.title: Which region is most involved in planning voluntary movements?
Briefly describe the role of the basal ganglia in movement.

title: Higher Cognition, Memory & Advanced Topics
description: Focuses on learning, memory formation, advanced cognitive functions, referencing Huberman & MIT course materials.

learningObjectives.description: Explain how memory is formed, stored, and retrieved, plus examine advanced cognitive functions (language, executive control)
assessmentCriteria: Differentiate short-term vs. long-term memory systems
Describe frontal lobe involvement in executive functions

resources.title: Andrew Huberman Lab: Neural Plasticity & Learning
resources.content: Podcasts/lectures discussing how the brain changes in response to learning

resources.title: MIT OCW: Memory and Cognition
resources.content: Exploring short-term vs. long-term memory, hippocampal function, consolidation

assignments.title: Memory Formation Paper
assignments.description: Write ~1200 words summarizing how LTP supports memory, referencing at least two studies from MIT or Huberman.

questions.title: Mechanisms of Memory
questions.description: Focus on hippocampal involvement, consolidation, or neural network changes.

assignments.title: Executive Function Project
assignments.description: Design a small experiment or observation testing executive control (e.g., a Stroop test). Summarize methodology & results.

questions.title: Experimental Setup
questions.description: Describe your participants, tasks, and data collection in 200 words.

questions.title: Analysis & Brain Regions
questions.description: Connect results to frontal cortex or other relevant brain areas from course material.

quizzes.title: Memory Systems Quiz
quizzes.description: Multiple-choice & short-answer on short-term vs. long-term memory, consolidation, and hippocampal function.

questions.title: Which brain structure is critical for forming new long-term memories?
Define 'memory consolidation' in 1-2 sentences.

quizzes.title: Advanced Cognition & Executive Function Quiz
quizzes.description: Short check on roles of the frontal lobe, language areas, and top-down control processes.

questions.title: Which region is often called the 'executive' of the brain?
Language production is typically associated with the temporal lobe.
